After 1000 hours, I'm still discovering new build interactions and optimization strategies. Undecember rewards dedication like few mobile games do, but demands significant investment to reach its potential. For the right player, it's an incredibly rewarding experience that can easily consume hundreds of hours of your time.
The game's complexity is both its greatest strength and biggest weakness - it offers depth that keeps you engaged for thousands of hours, but newcomers may bounce off before experiencing what makes it special.
Try it if you're an ARPG enthusiast, but be prepared for a significant learning investment before the game truly opens up.

What I enjoy most about Undecember is the freedom to create any kind of character. Swinging a sword while casting spells or summoning minions with a bow feels great. The grind is rewarding, the bosses are tough, and the Chaos Dungeons are pure fun. Definitely a solid hack & slash for fans of ARPGs.

Solid ARPG with deep character customization. Combat feels good, and there is a lot of build diversity to explore. While there are microtransactions, one can enjoy without spending money. Grindy, but rewarding if love the genre.

negative.review:
Has solid gameplay. The skill system is interesting. The end game, if you reach it is good.

However the campaign has multiple episodes and each is longer than all 10 acts of path of exiles campaign. To skip that, you have to pay 22$. The battlepass is 36$ for a month. The inventory is heavily restricted and to get one of the most important tabs (essence) is rougly 21$ but you need to buy a 36$ currency bundle to get it.

The campaign is about 5x longer than all of path of exiles campaign. The pricing is absurd and definitely priced for mobile. I would guess that Diablo Immortal is a better whale game if you want to drop this kind fo money on it.

It's also an app, which means it just doesn't have the quality for a really solid game as it pesters you with shop and transactions. Honestly though it could have been like a Path Of Exile game if it were just a bit better.

Yeah I can't get past the shitty B-Tier mobile game style marketing strategy. Whoever was in charge of that needs to get fired, as that is the primary reason this game failed miserably. The game mechanics are nice, though a bit overly convoluted for their results. Not many players will ever get far enough to explore that complexity though because the marketing tactics give a strong impression of "this is a shallow money grab like a generic mobile game" and scare them off. Even me, who tried to ignore it all and move past it. But with the constant popups of sales and shop events and random bullshit each time i go back to town, it was too difficult to ignore and ultimately frustrating as hell to see so much QoL that should just fucking be default, pushed behind subscription services.

Also, your auction house I saw took inspiration from Warframe's trading in the way it is premium currency economy. That only works if your game gets successful.

my internet connection gets choppy and the AI gave me a 24 hour ban for "using forbidden software". i'm not going to play or support a game that allows for such simple oversight, and punishing player's unjustly, and with no option to play offline if something this basic can happen.

remove ai from gaming if you cannot do it right.

The game itself isn't bad. But it's unplayable because every time I connect to the server, it instantly disconnects without explanation. After reading various forums, it's clear this has been going on for years, and the developers don't seem to care.

while this game is fun but sometimes bosses can be very annoying hard, they can one shot you,slow you down a lot or just make the space super small so you can't even dodge. the game wants to force you to pay real money to get better gear or literally revive your self anytime you die but only if you pay, stay away from this one it's a greedy game.

IDK why the devs allow marketing or whatever to absolutely ruin their games. Too many damn currencies, too much cash shop crap, too many "end game" systems that are almost entirely unfun to utilize (or in some stupid cases, level, like alchemy. NO ONE EVER LIKES ALCHEMY. EVER).

Next iteration: make your... "story"... optional. Give players *everything*. Use the cash shop for COSMETICS ONLY. Then your players will stay. This has been proven time and time and time again - the more pointless "grind skipping" and "annoyance skipping" you add to a cash shop, the exponentially less players you retain. So... maybe... juuuuuust maybe, *someone listens to the players who know better than you for once.*

Anyway. Good skill system. Decent itemization. But the "end game" loop sucks and you have to slog through a mindboggling amount of not-story-story to even get there. So much of the core which has AMAZING potential was absolutely destroyed by everything surrounding it.

Gave this a real shot I feel like. A lot to say and most of it is not good.

This is a very basic number go up ARPG with nothing really unique or especially interesting about it. If you've seen the quirky looking skill tree setup, you're in for a disappointment as it's very basic when it comes down to it.

Gameplay is incredibly easy, most of the content is a faceroll. In fact, you will be playing through 10s of hours of a pretty underwhelming campaign before you're allowed to engage with any of the game systems (enchanting, crafting, power building). Unintuitively, you'll be getting materials for these systems from the first moment you start the game, clogging up the inventory with you never really knowing what you'll be needing later on.

Loot is pretty underwhelming once you realize that you're not in it for gear items, but you're actually after ten billion different materials for crafting your own gear. This is the only point in the game you'll need help with and the resources for the game are relatively scarce. I said the game is easy but the power systems are incredibly convoluted and numerous, that most of your 300/400 slot inventory and storage will be swamped in various versions of materials you'll be hoarding for each individual system (there are also needlessly "exclusive" versions of items that don't stack with non-exclusive ones).

None of the things you do to get stronger are unique or innovative though, it's just different ways of getting the BIG NUMBER go up. There's very few conditional effects or things that will change how you play the game. Choose your main skill, set it on auto and tie it with another few skills and the game plays itself. You will stack the big number by grinding mats until your number goes into thousands/millions, then billions and then even TRILLIONS of DPS.

There are very few times where the game will test you for any sort of practical gameplay knowledge (other than your math and excell skills maybe) and you will either obliterate your enemies or you will be one shot by a regular mob that has 3000 times more damage than you have health. Very few in-between scenarios.

Campaign and story are bland and lazy, there is maybe one chapter that's even remotely interesting. Game also has bugs that can and will kill you.

Occasionally good art or design are overshadowed by the many flaws and shortcuts the game takes to either cut cost or make you buy into the plentiful shop where you can whale your brain off if you want to skip the grind. 

Easier to just skip the game altogether ;)

[i]Undecember[/i] left a bad impression almost immediately, and it never recovered. The gameplay itself feels choppy, almost like you’re constantly experiencing connection issues even when everything on your end is fine. Movement feels off, combat isn’t smooth, and nothing about the moment-to-moment gameplay feels satisfying.

Before you can even get a feel for the game, you’re bombarded with an absurd amount of pop-ups — battle passes, limited-time discounts, seasonal bundles, “free” boxes that all require you to open different store pages. It’s overwhelming, intrusive, and genuinely headache-inducing. And once you close all that, you’re pushed into a long string of forced tutorial clicks that go on far too long and kill the pacing before it even begins.

Even after escaping the tutorial treadmill, things don’t improve. Loot feels bland and unexciting, automatically vacuumed up just by running past it, with anything you miss being fetched by your pet. There’s no thrill in finding items, no meaningful impact from gear drops. The story didn’t offer anything compelling either — it felt too generic and uninspired to hold any interest.

The one system that [i]looked[/i] like it could have been interesting was the rune-based skill setup, with the potential for creative build crafting. But by the time I reached it, the rest of the experience had already soured so badly that I had no motivation left to explore it.

Overall, [i]Undecember[/i] feels messy, aggressively monetized, and unpleasant to play. Whatever potential the skill system might have had is buried under poor presentation, clunky gameplay, and an exhausting barrage of monetization tactics.

This is a very basic number go up ARPG with nothing really unique or especially interesting about it. If you've seen the quirky looking skill tree setup, you're in for a disappointment as it's very basic when it comes down to it.

Gameplay is incredibly easy, most of the content is a faceroll. In fact, you will be playing through 10s of hours of a pretty underwhelming campaign before you're allowed to engage with any of the game systems (enchanting, crafting, power building). Unintuitively, you'll be getting materials for these systems from the first moment you start the game, clogging up the inventory with you never really knowing what you'll be needing later on.

Loot is pretty underwhelming once you realize that you're not in it for gear items, but you're actually after ten billion different materials for crafting your own gear. This is the only point in the game you'll need help with and the resources for the game are relatively scarce. I said the game is easy but the power systems are incredibly convoluted and numerous, that most of your 300/400 slot inventory and storage will be swamped in various versions of materials you'll be hoarding for each individual system (there are also needlessly "exclusive" versions of items that don't stack with non-exclusive ones).

None of the things you do to get stronger are unique or innovative though, it's just different ways of getting the BIG NUMBER go up. There's very few conditional effects or things that will change how you play the game. Choose your main skill, set it on auto and tie it with another few skills and the game plays itself. You will stack the big number by grinding mats until your number goes into thousands/millions, then billions and then even TRILLIONS of DPS.

There are very few times where the game will test you for any sort of practical gameplay knowledge (other than your math and excell skills maybe) and you will either obliterate your enemies or you will be one shot by a regular mob that has 3000 times more damage than you have health. Very few in-between scenarios.

Campaign and story are bland and lazy, there is maybe one chapter that's even remotely interesting. Game also has bugs that can and will kill you.

Occasionally good art or design are overshadowed by the many flaws and shortcuts the game takes to either cut cost or make you buy into the plentiful shop where you can whale your brain off if you want to skip the grind. 

Easier to just skip the game altogether ;)

[i]Undecember[/i] left a bad impression almost immediately, and it never recovered. The gameplay itself feels choppy, almost like you’re constantly experiencing connection issues even when everything on your end is fine. Movement feels off, combat isn’t smooth, and nothing about the moment-to-moment gameplay feels satisfying.

Before you can even get a feel for the game, you’re bombarded with an absurd amount of pop-ups — battle passes, limited-time discounts, seasonal bundles, “free” boxes that all require you to open different store pages. It’s overwhelming, intrusive, and genuinely headache-inducing. And once you close all that, you’re pushed into a long string of forced tutorial clicks that go on far too long and kill the pacing before it even begins.

Even after escaping the tutorial treadmill, things don’t improve. Loot feels bland and unexciting, automatically vacuumed up just by running past it, with anything you miss being fetched by your pet. There’s no thrill in finding items, no meaningful impact from gear drops. The story didn’t offer anything compelling either — it felt too generic and uninspired to hold any interest.

The one system that [i]looked[/i] like it could have been interesting was the rune-based skill setup, with the potential for creative build crafting. But by the time I reached it, the rest of the experience had already soured so badly that I had no motivation left to explore it.

Overall, [i]Undecember[/i] feels messy, aggressively monetized, and unpleasant to play. Whatever potential the skill system might have had is buried under poor presentation, clunky gameplay, and an exhausting barrage of monetization tactics.
